awd_titl_txt: NRT-UtB: Science of learning, from neurobiology to real-world application: a problem-based approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning is the basis of human mental development and the process of learning continues throughout our lives. Perhaps more than anything else, how and what we learn shapes who we are. This project has the dual aims of achieving a deeper scientific understanding of learning, and communicating a deeper understanding of the science of learning to scientists and the public. Over several decades, diverse fields including genetics, neuroscience, linguistics, education, and psychology have generated a wealth of knowledge about myriad aspects of how humans learn, but a grand challenge remains: to integrate that knowledge into a unified understanding of learning based on these diverse fields, and on scales ranging from the gene to the neuron, brain, and human behavior. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to the University of Connecticut will help prepare the next generation of researchers to meet this challenge. The traineeship, focusing on the science of learning, will train fifty (50) PhD students, including twenty-five (25) funded trainees, from education, genetics, linguistics, psychology, neuroscience, and speech-language-hearing sciences. By emphasizing a problem-based approach (learning by doing), embracing collaboration across a broad a spectrum of disciplines, and integrating hands-on training in communication and leadership skills that enable effective multidisciplinary project design, management, and scientific discovery, this program will offer trainees unique preparation for a range of careers in academia, industry, and the public sector. 

The training program has five major components: an intensive one-year seminar that surveys the science of learning across all participating fields, a hands-on practicum where trainees learn to design and implement multidisciplinary research, faculty-student research interest groups that serve as brainstorming launch pads for new scientific challenges, data stewardship modules, and integrated training in outreach and communication. The seminar provides a cross-disciplinary introduction to the science of learning and the challenge of technical communication, while the practicum emphasizes practical skills crucial in academic and nonacademic careers that graduate education too often lacks: project design and management, budgeting and resource allocation, and external communications. The research interest groups, which will evolve as promising research proposals emerge from the practicum, serve as both focal point for research and organizational structure for the participants. From their first day in the program, students face the challenge of how to clearly and effectively share ideas without assuming prior knowledge or relying on technical jargon, a skill that not only enables excellence in research, but empowers trainees to become ambassadors for their work to society as a whole. This program will also promote diversity in careers requiring advanced training through best practices in recruitment and retention.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through comprehensive traineeship models that are innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

por.por_cntn:
Our ongoing theme (the program continues even after NSF funding) is "Science of Learning and Art of Communication". We bring together graduate students and faculty from biological fields, cognitive fields, and the arts with the aim of developing scientists of learning for whom interdisciplinary collaboration and clear communication (to audiences ranging from specialist peers to the general public) are second nature.

We had 4 major aims: 

1. Preparing diverse trainees for diverse career paths. We prepare trainees for diverse academic and/or nonacademic career paths through a rich environment designed to provide opportunities for trainees to develop knowledge and skills in biological and cognitive approaches to learning, experimental design, statistics, programming and data science. Our trainees will contribute to areas of national need related to learning, including understanding the brain, education, and learning technologies. We will build on successful mechanisms at our university for recruiting trainees from underrepresented groups to increase diversity.

2. Bridging fields and transforming project management culture. We will bridge gaps between and within biological and cognitive disciplines by recruiting PhD students from diverse fields (education, genetics, linguistics, four subfields of psychology, neuroscience, and speech-language-hearing sciences) for a training program that promotes interdisciplinary collaboration and best practices for project management. These best practices will be modeled in course projects as well as in new standard protocols for project management in inter-lab collaborations. Research teams will bring cutting-edge knowledge and techniques from these fields to bear on learning and memory in key domains (language, concepts, number/math, and education). Trainees will have opportunities to train in bridging tools and techniques, including neuroimaging and computational modeling.

3. Preparing trainees and faculty to be effective communicators. We draw on evidence-based practices (including the science of learning) for training students and faculty to communicate clearly and effectively. In particular, communication specialists work with our personnel drawing on techniques from traditional conservatory training to help individuals understand how to organize and present information in ways that make communication with audiences from specialist peers to scientists in other domains to the general public compelling and memorable. Trainees have opportunities to develop skills for speaking, blogging, film-making and web design, in addition to conventional scientific oral presentation and journal article writing. Our trainees have done impactful outreach at Connecticut public schools, the Connecticut Science Museum, and lifelong learning organizations. This training and these experiences will serve them well in academic and nonacademic career paths.

4. Tracking progress and effective practices. We implemented rigorous evaluation and assessment practices that allowed us to track impact on our trainees, in part by comparing them with a control group of PhD students from their programs who are not participating in this NRT, with the aim of refining our practices to make them more effective.

 

Successes

Our trainees were involved in collaborations that have already led to 132 publications during the funding period (many more are still under review or in progress). These publications included cutting-edge work at the intersections of psychology and artificial intelligence, psychology and linguistics, neuroscience and education, and many more. 

 

Our trainees who have graduated have gone on to excellent placements in academic positions and in industry. 

 

Our NSF funding directly supported 25 PhD students with at least 12 months of stipends, allowing them freedom to engage in interdisciplinary research while pursuing our intensive laboratory- and course-based training. Nearly as many PhD students fully participated as 'associate' trainees, completing all program components. In addition, literally hundreds of other students were impacted by participating in some of our activities, including an undergraduate honors course developed by the PI where students learned fundamental  principles of the science of learning and then developed strong communication skills by working in teams to create evidence-based persuasive presentations about learning. 

 

Most importantly, from our perspective, NSF funding gave us the resources and time needed to build (over 5 years) a community where interdisciplinary collaboration is the standard rather than the exception, and where our courses are infused with training in science communication that enhances our scientific writing and presentations to colleagues in our own fields, adjacent and distant fields, and to the general public (of all ages).
